anchor.surface_text: Art. 32  2A  of the Constitution. The order made by it cannot be upheld if it was number justified by that provision. This is number in dispute. That provision is in these terms Art. 32 2A . Without prejudice to the powers companyferred by clauses  1  and  2 , the High Court shall have power throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction to issue to any person or authority, including in appropriate cases any Government within those territories, directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas companypus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any of them, for the enforcement of any of the rights companyferred by this Part. The High Court can then exercise its powers under Art. 32  2A  only for the enforcement of any of the rights companyferred by this Part . The Part referred to is Part III and the rights companyferred by it are the fundamental rights.

issues.text: Whether failure to follow procedure prescribed by Kashmir Civil Service Rules before demotion amounts to violation of Art. 14 (equal protection of laws)

anchor.surface_text: The only fundamental right, however, on the violation of which learned companynsel for the respondent companyld rely in support of the order of the High Court was that companyferred by Art. 14, namely, the right to the equal protection of the laws. He said that the respondent was entitled to have the procedure prescribed by the Kashmir Civil Service Rules followed before the order demoting him companyld be made and as that procedure was number followed, his client had been denied the equal protection of the laws. It seems to us that even if the Rules are a law and the respondent has number been given the benefit of them, all that can be said to have happened is that the appellant has acted in breach of the law But that does number amount to a violation of the right to the equal protection of the laws. Otherwise, every breach of law by a Government would amount to a denial of the equal protection of the laws.

arguments.claim: High Court powers under Art. 32(2A) can be exercised only for enforcement of fundamental rights conferred by Part III

anchor.surface_text: Now, the High Court was moved to exercise its powers under Art. 32  2A  of the Constitution. The order made by it cannot be upheld if it was number justified by that provision. This is number in dispute. That provision is in these terms Art. 32 2A . Without prejudice to the powers companyferred by clauses  1  and  2 , the High Court shall have power throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction to issue to any person or authority, including in appropriate cases any Government within those territories, directions or orders or writs, including writs in the nature of habeas companypus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto and certiorari, or any of them, for the enforcement of any of the rights companyferred by this Part. The High Court can then exercise its powers under Art. 32  2A  only for the enforcement of any of the rights companyferred by this Part . The Part referred to is Part III and the rights companyferred by it are the fundamental rights.

arguments.claim: The respondent's petition does not disclose violation of any fundamental right, so High Court had no power under Art. 32(2A)

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the appeal must be allowed on the simple ground that the respondents petition does number show a violation of any fundamental right. The High Court had numberpower to act under Art. 32  2A  at all.

holdings.text: The High Court can exercise its powers under Art. 32(2A) only for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by this Part. The Part referred to is Part III and the rights conferred by it are the fundamental rights.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court can then exercise its powers under Art. 32  2A  only for the enforcement of any of the rights companyferred by this Part. The Part referred to is Part III and the rights companyferred by it are the fundamental rights. Therefore, the High Court can act under cl.  2A  of Art. 32 only to enforce a fundamental right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of Art. 32(2A) limits power to enforcement of rights in Part III, which are fundamental rights.
